body: For years, John Jay High School, on Seventh Avenue near Fourth Street, has been troubled, ranking high among the city's schools in assaults and robberies and low in test scores and graduation rates. John Jay is situated in the prosperous heart of Park Slope, but many parents there never dreamed of sending their children to the school. The local
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; School Board May Try to Take Over Troubled John Jay

body: NEARLY every fine Saturday and Sunday from spring to fall, some residents of Park Slope, Brooklyn, change personality, as if howling at the sun. body: WITH all the scarcity, hysteria, back-stabbing and astronomical prices in the real estate market, it would hardly seem possible for young people just out of college to find apartments. But while apartments go quickly, they can be found, even for those more interested in what they do than in what they earn. Regardless of whether they are making
title: For Class of '99, A Real-Life 'Rent'

body: BEYOND the plusher precincts of Manhattan, New York City's co-op and condominium market has been steadily gaining strength, bringing welcome financial news and a palpable sense of relief to many apartment owners. The market had been dormant, if not on life support, for the first half of this decade. Those were the bad old days: a time when promises
title: Troubled Co-ops Outside Manhattan Are on the Rebound

body: A man who exposed himself to young girls twice in a single morning was still on the loose as the school week ended on Friday. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WINDSOR TERRACE; Man Who Exposed Himself to Two Young Girls Is Sought

body: When the Board of Education divvied up the $10.9 billion it plans to spend on construction, repair and renovation in the next five years, it allotted some districts hundreds of millions of dollars to build schools.
